Steinbrenner Lab

The University of Washington, Seattle

Steinbrenner lab members

Current grads, postdocs, and staff

Di Wu
Postdoctoral Researcher
woody63 /at/ uw.edu
Di joined the lab in November 2023 as a postdoctoral researcher, bringing a diverse background in plant immune signaling and plant-herbivore interactions. Currently, he is investigating the spatial aspects of INR-mediated defense, along with screening for additional components in the INR-mediated pathways.

Brian Behnken
Research Technician
bbehnken /at/ uw.edu
Brian is a microbiology major with the intention of pursuing a PhD in immunology. He joined the lab in winter of 2022 and is looking forward to learning about plant immune systems. His interests include research and reading anything from physics to biology, and outside of the academy he enjoys backpacking, finding any excuse to make curry, and create art.

Ben Sheppard
Graduate Student
bdshep /at/ uw.edu
Ben joined the UW Department of Biology in September 2021.

Natalia Guayazan-Palacios
Graduate Student
nguaya /at/ uw.edu
I am a USDA-NIFA predoctoral fellow studying the molecular mechanisms that regulate plant-induced defenses. During my BSc and MSc, I focused on plant pathogens and the cellular and transcriptomic changes they undergo during plant host colonization. Although a microbiologist at heart, I always wondered “How do plants fend off invaders?” as I saw my favorite plant pathogen struggle to colonize a new host. This question stayed with me, ultimately leading me to the Steinbrenner lab where I currently explore the regulation of herbivore- and pathogen-induced defenses in legumes through an approach that integrates transcriptomics, molecular biology, biochemistry, and bioassays with herbivores and microbes. Twitter: @nataliagupa.


Adam Steinbrenner
Principal Investigator
astein10 /at/ uw.edu
Associate Professor, UW Dept. of Biology
HHMI Postdoctoral Fellow, UC San Diego (2016-2019)
PhD 2015, UC Berkeley Dept. of Plant & Microbial Biology
BS 2010, Tufts University

I am fascinated by plant immune systems. Building on my training in chemical ecology and molecular genetics of immune receptors, my lab now explores new aspects of plant immunity, often using comparative, evolutionary, and synthetic biology lenses. I love working with excited, creative trainees to develop projects on these topics.
